facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2201 and 2202 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2201 and 2202 of 1966. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated September 15, 1966 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petitions Nos. 351 and 311 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated September 15, 1966 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petitions Nos. 351 and 311 of 1965 respectively.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation constituted under Road Transport Corporation Act No. 64 of 1950, came into existence in May 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Madhya Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation  hereinafter referred to as the Corporation , companystituted under the Road Transport Corporation Act,  No. 64 of 1950 , came into existence in May 1962 to operate

facts.text: Corporation operates as State Transport Undertaking under s. 68-A of Motor Vehicles Act No. 4 of 1939.

anchor.surface_text: in May 1962 to operate as a State Transport Undertaking under s. 68-A of the Motor Vehicles Act, No. 4 of 1939,  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Corporation passed two resolutions in April and May 1964 to take over certain routes under Chapter IV-A of the Act to exclusion of private operators.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation passed two resolutions in April and May 1964 by which it decided to take over certain routes under Chapter IV-A of the Act to the exclusion of the existing private operators on those routes.

facts.text: Schemes Nos. 16 and 22 dated May 11, 1964 published by Corporation inviting objections within 30 days.

anchor.surface_text: Two schemes, namely, Nos. 16 and 22 dated May 11, 1964, were published by the Corporation inviting objections within 30 days. The schemes appeared in the Government Gazette of May 22, 1964

facts.text: Schemes appeared in Government Gazette on May 22, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The schemes appeared in the Government Gazette of May 22, 1964 and objections thereto were filed by private operators affected thereby within the period prescribed.

facts.text: Objections filed by private operators within prescribed period.

anchor.surface_text: and objections thereto were filed by private operators affected thereby within the period prescribed. Thereafter the authority empowered to hear objections under s. 68-D of the Act

facts.text: Authority under s.68-D gave notices fixing date for hearing, to begin on September 4, 1964, postponed several times, arguments heard on May 20, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the authority empowered to hear objections under s. 68-D of the Act gave numberices fixing a date for hearing. The hearing was to begin on September 4, 1964, but it was postponed a number of times. Finally, arguments were heard on May 20, 1965.

facts.text: Authority passed orders on June 8, 1965 modifying the schemes.

anchor.surface_text: The authority passed orders on June 8, 1965 modifying the schemes in certain particulars. On June 11, 1965, the modified schemes were published,

facts.text: Modified schemes published on June 11, 1965, corrected schemes published on June 18, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: On June 11, 1965, the modified schemes were published, but as there were mistakes in them, companyrected schemes as modified were finally published on June 18, 1965.

facts.text: Writ petitions filed to High Court in August 1965 by private operators dissatisfied with authority's order.

anchor.surface_text: Then followed writ petitions to the High Court in August 1965 by private operators who were dissatisfied with the order of the -authority companycerned.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petitions, rejecting contentions of petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the writ petitions rejecting all the companytentions raised by the petitioners before it. Thereafter the High Court gave certificates to appeal to this Court,

facts.text: High Court granted certificates to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the High Court gave certificates to appeal to this Court, and that is how the appeals have companye before us.

facts.text: Petitioners contended that proposed schemes published on May 22, 1964 were not in compliance with s.68-C as they did not give necessary particulars for four-fold purposes.

anchor.surface_text: The first companytention raised before us is that the proposed schemes published on May 22, 1964 were bad inasmuch as they were number in companypliance with s. 68-C of the Act and the rules

facts.text: High Court rejected contention that schemes lacked compliance with s.68-C.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected this companytention holding that there was sufficient companypliance with the provisions companytained in s. 68-C and the. rules framed thereunder

facts.text: Special Secretary heard objections on behalf of State Government, appointed under Rules of Business under Art.166(3).

anchor.surface_text: The second companytention is that the Special Secretary who heard the objections on behalf of the State Government was number validly authorised to do so inasmuch as he had been appointed under the Rules of Business

facts.text: Petitioners contended Special Secretary not validly authorised, should be under s.68-D(2-a).

anchor.surface_text: inasmuch as he had been appointed under the Rules of Business framed under Art. 166  3  of the Constitution while appointment should have been under s. 68-D 2-a  of the Act,

facts.text: High Court held s.68-D(2-a) supplementary to Rules of Business.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court re- jected this companytention holding that the provision in s. 68-D  2-a  was supplementary to the power which the State Government had under the Rules of Business

facts.text: Authority passed order approving schemes on June 8, 1965 without expressly stating schemes fulfilled s.68-C purposes.

anchor.surface_text: The third companytention is that the order approving the schemes passed on June 8, 1965 was invalid inasmuch as it did number say that the schemes fulfilled the purposes mentioned in s. 68-C.

facts.text: Petitioners contended hearing by authority was not adequate and real.

anchor.surface_text: The last companytention is that the hearing given by the authority was number adequate and real and therefore the approval given was invalid.

facts.text: Appellants requested authority to summon documents from Corporation and witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that an application was made by the appellants requesting the authority to summon a very large number of documents from the Corporation in order to prove inter alia that the present equipment

facts.text: Authority refused to summon witnesses and some documents as irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: As for the witnesses, the authority refused to summon them on the ground that their evidence would be irrelevant and in any case oral testimony was number necessary to prove what the appellants desired to prove.

issues.text: Whether the proposed schemes published on May 22, 1964 were bad inasmuch as they were not in compliance with s. 68-C of the Act and the rules framed thereunder, for they did not give necessary particulars which would enable the appellants to formulate their objections to the proposed schemes in respect of the four-fold purposes mentioned in s. 68-C?

anchor.surface_text: The first companytention raised before us is that the proposed schemes published on May 22, 1964 were bad inasmuch as they were number in companypliance with s. 68-C of the Act and the rules framed thereunder, for they did number give necessary particulars

anchor.surface_text: The second companytention is that the Special Secretary who heard the objections on behalf of the State Government was number validly authorised to do so inasmuch as he had been appointed under the Rules of Business framed under Art. 166  3  of the Constitution

arguments.claim: Hearing under s.68-D quasi-judicial; must consider relevant evidence but can reject irrelevant; no coercive powers without rules.

anchor.surface_text: The first case to which reference may be made is Gullapalli Nageswara Rao Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation in which this Court by majority held that the hearing under s. 68-D(2) was quasi judicial in nature

arguments.claim: No provision in Act/rules for summoning witnesses/compelling documents; authority cannot compel but can consider voluntary evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged on behalf of the Corporation that there is no provision in the Act and the Rules framed thereunder in Madhya Pradesh applying the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure with respect to summoning of witnesses

arguments.claim: Comparative merits/finances irrelevant in Ch.IV-A nationalisation; State undertaking has govt backing; integrated service vs individual operators.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that this Chapter was introduced in the Act in 1956 after Art. 19(6) of the Constitution had been amended by the Constitution First Amendment Act, 1951.

arguments.claim: American cases requiring express findings distinguished; no such requirement in s.68-C/D.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in this connection is placed on certain American cases which hold that the lack of an express finding necessary under a statute to validate an order of an administrative agency cannot be supplied by implication.

holdings.text: The proposed schemes published on May 22, 1964 are in compliance with s. 68-C of the Act and the rules framed thereunder as they give particulars of the nature of services, routes, and prescribed matters, which is sufficient to enable objections; no need to disclose detailed data supporting the four purposes.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this argument must be rejected. The schemes have given sufficient details to enable the appellants to file their objections. The four purposes mentioned in s. 68-C are so all-embracing in their nature that it would always be possible for a private operator to put forward some small particular and say that this particular should also have been given in the proposed scheme and as it is not given it is not possible for him to make a proper objection with respect to the four purposes mentioned in the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.68-C mandates specific particulars (nature of services, routes, prescribed); four purposes too broad for inclusion, would lead to endless challenges invalidating all schemes; sufficient for formulating objections.

holdings.text: Appointment of Special Secretary under Rules of Business (Art.166(3)) is valid to hear objections under s.68-D; s.68-D(2-a) substantive part (rank not below Secretary) mandatory and satisfied, procedural part (notification) directory and alternative to Rules permissible.

anchor.surface_text: The second contention is that the Special Secretary who heard the objections on behalf of the State Government was not validly authorised. Now s. 68-D (2) provides that the State Government may, after considering the objections and after giving an opportunity to the objector or his representatives and the representatives of the State Transport Undertaking to be heard in the matter,if they so desire, approve or modify the scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Divides s.68-D(2-a) into substantive (rank) mandatory and procedural (notification) directory; no exclusion of constitutional Rules of Business; harmonious construction allows either method if rank complied.

holdings.text: No express finding required in approval order under s.68-D that schemes fulfill s.68-C purposes; approval or modification implies such determination.

anchor.surface_text: The third contention raised on behalf of the appellants is that the orders approving and modifying the schemes in this case do not show that the authority had applied its mind to the question whether the schemes were such as to subserve the purposes of providing an efficient, adequate economical and properly coordinated transport service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory mandate for express finding; object of s.68-D hearing is to assess purposes; approval necessarily implies positive determination; distinguishes American cases requiring express findings.

holdings.text: Hearing under s.68-D was adequate and real; authority correctly refused irrelevant evidence on Corporation's equipment, finances, past record, and witnesses as such comparative merits irrelevant to nationalisation schemes under Chapter IV-A.

anchor.surface_text: The last contention is that an adequate and real hearing was not given to the appellants as required by S. 68-D of the Act. [...] It appears that an application was made by the appellants requesting the authority to summon a very large number of documents from the Corporation in order to prove inter alia that the present equipment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial hearing per precedents requires relevant evidence; no statutory power to compel witnesses/documents; evidence sought irrelevant as State undertakings backed by govt resources, no comparative merits in policy of nationalisation post Art.19(6) amendment; integrated service vs individual operators.

holdings.text: Authority under s.68-D has no power to compel attendance of witnesses or production of documents absent provision in Act or rules applying CPC.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged on behalf of the Corporation that there is no provision in the Act and the Rules framed thereunder in Madhya Pradesh applying the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure with respect to summoning of witnesses

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Act/rules; precedents (Gullapalli, Malik Ram, Nehru Motor) confirm quasi-judicial but limited to voluntary/relevant evidence; may request but no coercive process.

holdings.text: In nationalisation under Chapter IV-A, no question of comparative merits between State Transport Undertaking and private operators; equipment/finances/past record irrelevant given govt backing and integrated service policy.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that this Chapter was introduced in the Act in 1956 after Art. 19(6) of the Constitution had been amended by the Constitution First Amendment Act, 1951. By that amendment the State was given power relating to the carrying on by it or by a Corporation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation post constitutional amendment enabling monopoly; s.68-A(b) entities govt-controlled; schemes inherently public interest if serve four purposes; comparison futile.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this argument must be rejected. The schemes have given sufficient details to enable the appellants to file their objections. The four purposes mentioned in s. 68-C are so all-embracing in their nature that it would always be possible for a private operator to put forward some small particular and say that this particular should also have been given in the proposed scheme and as it is not given it is not possible for him to make a proper objection with respect to the four purposes mentioned in the section.
In the result the High Court dismissed the writ petitions after rejecting other points which were raised before the High Court but are number raised before us.

anchor.surface_text: The second contention is that the Special Secretary who heard the objections on behalf of the State Government was not validly authorised.
